TicTacToe Environment 1.3.0 API

See:
          Description

Packages
de.ovgu.dke.teaching.ml.tictactoe Main classes for playing a Match or Tournament.
de.ovgu.dke.teaching.ml.tictactoe.api Common interfaces for a TicTacToe board, player and move.
de.ovgu.dke.teaching.ml.tictactoe.game Game logic, rules and a tournament class.
de.ovgu.dke.teaching.ml.tictactoe.player Player classes, e.g a Random Player or Keyboard Player.
de.ovgu.dke.teaching.ml.tictactoe.util Utility stuff

 

This document describes the source code of the "TicTacToe Environment".

This TicTacToe environment allows to play a match of TicTacToe on a 3-dimensional board. All required classes are located in the lib directory. Configuration is done using Java Property files in the config directory. New players can be implemented in the src directory.

Everything should be quite self-explanatory. If not, contact me ;)

Author: Thomas Low (thomas.low@ovgu.de)

Changelog

  • v1.3.0 (Oct-22-2013)

    • Added start and compile scripts for Linux and Windows
    • Moved README content into Javadoc overview file

  • v1.2.1 (Oct-29-2012)

    • Added command for compiling NewPlayer.java in Windows.
    • Fixed package declaration in NewPlayer.java.

  • v1.2.0 (Oct-22-2012)

    • Some minor changes (javadoc, readme file)

  • v1.1.0 (Nov-01-2011)

    • Added onMatchEnds method to IPlayer interface, which is called with the final board.
    • Fixed: Some 2d diagonals of the 3d board were not recognized as winning rows properly.

Configuration

In order to configure this TicTacToe game, you can edit the file config/tictactoe.properties and change its values. It contains references to classes of players which play in a match or tournament. You can also define the size of the board and the number of rounds in a tournament.

There are three players available:

  • KeyboardPlayer - asks the user to enter the next move
  • RandomPlayer - chooses random moves
  • SmartPlayer - uses some more or less intelligent rules

In order to choose a player, the property player has to be modified, e.g.:

player=KeyboardPlayer:RandomPlayer

Each player is identified by its class name and the package it resides in (separated by colon). For example, a player that is implemented by a class called MyPlayer located in package mypackage can be referenced as mypackage.MyPlayer. For tournaments, more than two players can be specified, e.g.:

player=mypackage.MyPlayer:yourpackage.YourPlayer:SmartPlayer:RandomPlayer

Starting a Match

Starting a simple match between two players is easy. Simply add two ore more players to the configuration file (already done by me) and execute the PlayMatch class. In Linux this can be done using this command:

java -cp "config:src:lib/*" de.ovgu.dke.teaching.ml.tictactoe.PlayMatch

In Windows classpaths are separated by a semicolon. You might need to substitute ":" with ";", e.g.:

java -cp "config;src;lib/*" de.ovgu.dke.teaching.ml.tictactoe.PlayMatch

Starting a Tournament

Starting a tournament between a set of players is very similar. Add all players to the configuration file and execute:

java -cp "config:src:lib/*" de.ovgu.dke.teaching.ml.tictactoe.PlayTournament

Again, in Windows you probably need to write:

java -cp "config;src;lib/*" de.ovgu.dke.teaching.ml.tictactoe.PlayTournament

Develop your own player

In order to develop your own player, your class needs to implement the IPlayer interface. Check out src/NewPlayer.java for an example. When your are ready, compile your player by executing:

javac -cp "lib/*" src/NewPlayer.java

Then you can start a match or tournament, after adding your new player class to the configuration file. For example, edit tictactoe.properties like this:

player=NewPlayer:RandomPlayer

For development, you might want to test certain board scenarios. The easiest way to do this, is to play against KeyboardPlayer, which can be controlled with your keyboard.

Don't forget to give your player a unique name. That's it. Have fun!

Play against others

Simply ask your classmates to send you their player classes and add them to the configuration file.

You might also want to play against SmartPlayer. He's quite good.

Some random information

This project uses Apache Maven for dependency management. Logging is done using SLF4J and Log4J.

References:

  • http://maven.apache.org/
  • http://www.slf4j.org/
  • http://logging.apache.org/log4j/
